Good morning everyone!
Thanks a lot, Colin, these were very good ideas you =
had! I spent the 
whole day and night checking everything, but I haven't fo=
und my 
mistake so far. But I made some interesting discoveries, which I ho=
pe 
help me find the culprit or at least point me in the right direction. 
=
I tried different settings with the 1joint condition and everything 
worked=
 out fine (against my earlier expectations). 
1. I started with the easiest=
 task: 3 random start angles (0=B0-180=B0), 
1 goal angle (90=B0). Time ela=
psed until perfect movement was observed: 
30 generations.
2a. 3 random sta=
rt angles (0=B0-180=B0), 3 differnt goal angles (45=B0, 
90=B0, 135=B0). 50=
 generations until perfect behavior.
2b. Same as 2a, but with 12 random sta=
rt angles. 70 generations.
3. 3 random start angles (0=B0-180=B0), 3 random=
 goal angles (30=B0-150=B0). 
90 generations.

Although more generations we=
re needed with increasing task complexity 
(and I think the time needed is =
appropriate, taking into account that 
gravity has to be masterd, or am I w=
rong?), all of the above tasks 
was solved with very good resulting behavio=
ur. Then I started to add 
a second joint and suddenly everything was back =
to normal (which in 
my case means: bad). 
4. 1st joint: 3 random start and=
 3 random goal angles (0=B0-180=B0). 2nd 
joint: 3 random start and 3 rando=
m goal angles (0=B0-360=B0). Observed 
behaviour: until generation 50 fast =
improvements, generation 50-100 
minor improvements, generation 100-600 no =
improvements at all.

Judging from the above mentioned data, I would sugges=
t two 
possibilites:
A. The 1st joint works well, meaning I made a mistake =
concerning the 
2nd joint (and all following) which makes it impossible for=
 NEAT to 
solve the problem (e.g. not all of the necessary input is provide=
d).
B. There is a more general mistake I made, resulting in lower 
performa=
nce with increasing task complexity and concerning not only 
the 2nd joint =
but all joints in general (e.g. an error in the 
communication between NEAT=
 and the simulator).

Personally, I would vote for A, so as long as nobody =
disagrees (for 
example, because you think the 1st joint should learn much =
faster 
these easy tasks), I will try some easier tasks with 2joints (like =

the ones with 1joint, e.g. with one joint having a non-random goal 
angle)=
 in order to narrow down the field.

I can't thank you guys enough, it's ve=
ry good to have someone with 
fresh ideas listening to one's problems. I wa=
s really desperated as I 
made no progress at all over the last weeks, but =
now I'm full of hope 
to get it right in the end.
With best regards,
Matthi=
as
